ingredients_for_the_heart: I can relate to this too well. Yep also in my yoga classes. I live in one of the whitest utopia, Portland, Oregon. Basically white people colonized my space all day long. 😠

faharibazaar: I think here in America, people are generally not taught to share or see themselves as part of a whole. And even though everyone preaches that sharing is caring, it's never practiced. The mentality is me, me, me. I have witnessed this lack of sharing or consideration when you walk into a room for a meeting/workshop and people are already seated around a table. You can see how agitated and defensive about space people get when they have to move a little to make room for an extra chair. It boggles my mind! I grew up with over 20 siblings, aunts, cousins, grandparents etc. With so many people in one compound, you learn from a very young age to make space for others, to consider others, to feel responsibility for others, and to share with others. There was never "me" when I was growing up. So that by the time you are an adult, it bothers you that you have space and someone else doesn't. You feel when others are hurting. You ask yourself who hasn't eaten when serving food for yourself. And you don't think that you matter more and so deserve to take from everyone else. I see this attitude that people have about sharing as a lacking. I always tell people, "you can't teach what you don't know. You can't give what you lack." If you don't learn to share or be considerate when growing up, you will never be able to give those things to others.

ggbostini: I live to avoid conflict and attn in anyway in public (anxious introvert strategies 101), when I took group classes a decade ago, I’d go to the front or back corner, no one could tell me to move.....but I saw this all the time.
